üéÆ From Your guide to intelligent, nonviolent video games:

The Talos Principle (2014): A puzzle game in the tradition of philosophical science fiction, the Talos Principle asks questions about existence, the self, artificial intelligence, humanity and God. The player is an android who awakens in a strange garden and is given instructions by a booming voice from the sky to complete a series of trials. Among these puzzles, a sentient computer database tempts you, like the serpent in the garden of Eden, to climb a forbidden tower.

That sounds like an interesting game. That’s just the first in the list though. There’s more games listed in that article.

items.content_html: The Telerik JustDecompile tool is great for helping troubleshoot build issues. Was assisting someone who was running into a WCF service error. The service method reported in the error was nowhere to be found in the codebase I was looking at. I verified that by using JustDecompile to look at the compiled code in one of the related DLLs on the test server. Turns out the client app he was running, was a newer version, while the service it connected to ran the old code.
items.content_text: The Telerik JustDecompile tool is great for helping troubleshoot build issues. Was assisting someone who was running into a WCF service error. The service method reported in the error was nowhere to be found in the codebase I was looking at. I verified that by using JustDecompile to look at the compiled code in one of the related DLLs on the test server. Turns out the client app he was running, was a newer version, while the service it connected to ran the old code.

items.content_html:
But we might ask ourselves the same question about the story of our faith. A story of lives called, hardships suffered, and death certain. To a point, Christianity is a story of abject failure. Of Jobs and Judases, of Passions and prisons. If to unbelievers it is a fairy tale, then it is a very dark fairy tale. And yet we know that all of this suffering isn‚Äôt for naught. What seems a story of loss is in fact the most brilliant, if not stealthy, triumph. Enveloped in pain and suffering, the Christian narrative sneaks in tender mercies and unexpected miracles, loving acts and timeless wisdom. And it is all capped off with an unfathomable Resurrection. There is grace that ultimately and completely washes away the devastation of man. There is a faith that understands the larger story.

I never thought of it that way. But he‚Äôs right, what a story it is.

The man who had forgotten who he was is reminded of the dignity he had forgotten. This is why I teach King Lear. And why I love it. This is what I want my medical students and residents to understand. That though we are broken and complex, our dignity (and the dignity of our patients) is independent of status, power, or possessions. And sometimes, in this world of tragedy‚Äîa world that sometimes just doesn‚Äôt give a damn about you or me‚Äîwe need to be reminded and to remind others of the dignity that we have forgotten. The dignity of being a child of God.

His students are lucky to have him as their teacher and mentor.

~ Finding Grace in the Consuming Blackness of ‚ÄúKing Lear‚Äù

items.content_html:
Procrastination is really deferred progress for no good reason. One cause is that a task seems to big, or you feel like you don‚Äôt have the time or energy to complete the task.

Jim Kwik introduces the concept of Small Simple Steps (or S cubed).

The essence of this approach is for any task that you find you are procrastinating on, pick a small part (step) of the task to start on. The key thing is to pick a step that is so small and so simple that you cannot fail at it.

~ Prevent Procrastination With This One Simple Tip

items.content_html:
Ran into an issue where I could not open rptproj files with Visual Studio 2019. Since these were old SSRS reports, I thought I’d try opening them with Visual Studio 2013. Didn’t work either. Visual Studio 2012? Nope.

Did some more research and eventually found out that this is not a Visual Studio issue. Apparently, to open rptproj files with Visual Studio, you need to install the corresponding Microsoft SQL Server Data Tools - Business Intelligence package. Would not have figured that out had it not been for this post.

So I went here to download the SQL Server Data Tools BI package. Installed it. And now I can open the SSRS solution/project in Visual Studio 2012.

items.content_html:
Walking is increasingly mediated by technological gadgets worn on wrists or gripped in hands. We spend an increasing amount of time ‚Äòscreening‚Äô the world ‚Äì taking in most of life through a contracted frame that captures objects of immediate interest. To live with eyes on the screen is to be attached, stuck in the frame, taking in what is presented to us and re-presented to us again. But representation ‚Äì even in fine-grained pixilation ‚Äì is not experience. To experience is to perceive. When we look at a screen, we might see something, but we don‚Äôt perceive. To live life through representations is to live passively, to receive rather than to experience.

~ For the full life experience, put down all devices and walk

items.content_html: Don’t pass an object into a method if all you really need are some of its property values. Say you have a Customer object with properties like FirstName, LastName, EmailAddress, etc… If all you really need are just a few of those property values, then pass in those individual values instead of passing in the object itself. A method with a signature like DoSomething(string firstName, string lastName, string emailAddress) is easier to maintain and write tests for, than something like DoSomething(Customer customer).

items.content_html: I’ve ran into a number of articles these past few days talking about software design principles and design patterns. I ran into one that talked about how we should move beyond SOLID design principles. I’m also reading another talking about Postel’s Law and its downsides. What I’ve learned from reading these articles, is that the most important skill software developers need with regards to software design principles and design patterns, is to know when to use them. Each design principle/pattern can come with some downsides, so it is best to be able to determine whether you need to implement them in the first place.
items.content_text: I've ran into a number of articles these past few days talking about software design principles and design patterns. I ran into one that talked about how we should [move beyond SOLID design principles](http://qualityisspeed.blogspot.com/2014/09/beyond-solid-dependency-elimination.html). I'm also reading another talking about [Postel's Law](https://ardalis.com/postels-law-robustness-principle/) and its downsides. What I've learned from reading these articles, is that the most important skill software developers need with regards to software design principles and design patterns, is to know when to use them. Each design principle/pattern can come with some downsides, so it is best to be able to determine whether you need to implement them in the first place.

items.title: How To Add Hyvor Talk Comments to Micro.blog-hosted Blog
items.content_html:
I’ve been looking for a way to add comments to this blog. It’s specifically for my friends who don’t have a Micro.blog account. I saw someone mention Hyvor Talk back when I just joined Micro.blog. I thought I’d give it a try. It turns out to be relatively easy to install. You’ll need to be using a custom theme to do this. I used the instructions to add Disqus comments as reference.

First step is to add canonical tags to the blog. I modified layouts/partials/head.html and added a canonical tag just above the css link tags. I tried to copy the code itself here, but I keep running into issues with Hugo not wanting to show it. So, you’ll get a picture instead.

Next step is to sign-up for Hyvor Talk. Choose “Manual Installation”. Copy the code/script that they provide and paste it inside layouts/post/single.html just before the last {{ end }} at the bottom of the file.

And that’s it.
items.content_text: I've been looking for a way to add comments to this blog. It's specifically for my friends who don't have a Micro.blog account. I saw someone mention Hyvor Talk back when I just joined Micro.blog. I thought I'd give it a try. It turns out to be relatively easy to install. You'll need to be using a [custom theme](https://help.micro.blog/2019/about-themes/) to do this. I used the [instructions to add Disqus comments](https://help.micro.blog/2019/disqus/) as reference. First step is to add canonical tags to the blog. I modified layouts/partials/head.html and added a canonical tag just above the css link tags. I tried to copy the code itself here, but I keep running into issues with Hugo not wanting to show it. So, you'll get a picture instead. Next step is to sign-up for [Hyvor Talk](https://talk.hyvor.com/). Choose "Manual Installation". Copy the code/script that they provide and paste it inside layouts/post/single.html just before the last {{ end }} at the bottom of the file. And that's it.

items.content_html:
And although TV and video games of course offer escapism, there‚Äôs nothing quite like devouring the pages of a beautiful novel, sitting quietly in one place while letting words transport you to another. Screens show you what‚Äôs happening; novels, by contrast, construct those fictions within your mind, allowing you to become anyone, and go anywhere.
~ How to read more books by Christian Jarrett

Hmmm I’d put books and videogames on the same level. It’s also very much dependent on how good a book and videogame is. While a good book can allow your mind to wander into a wonderful world full of possibilities, at the end of the day, you’re still following the story. A really good videogame on the other hand, gives you a world to play in and let’s you write your own story.

items.content_html: Any time you are writing IO code, like something that saves or moves files to different locations, you should wrap the code in a try-catch. Without a try-catch, if one of the “move file” attempts fail, the whole process breaks down and you end up losing your files.
items.content_text: Any time you are writing IO code, like something that saves or moves files to different locations, you should wrap the code in a try-catch. Without a try-catch, if one of the "move file" attempts fail, the whole process breaks down and you end up losing your files.

Many church goers have been unable to participate in the liturgy for months. Some are just now beginning to return. Where is the grace in this hiatus and slow trickle back? Perhaps it gives us a chance to pause and ask ourselves where chasms have formed between how we regard and treat others with the radical faith Jesus gifted us.

Perhaps, it gives us a moment to simply ask: What‚Äôs the point of going, if the bread changes, but we don‚Äôt?
~ Sometimes I Wonder, What If the Bread Changes but We Don‚Äôt? by Christopher Alt, SJ

items.content_text: Years ago, my definition of *afford* was, if I can keep paying the monthly payment, I can *afford* it. Nowadays that definition has changed to, if I can't buy it with cash, then I can't *afford* it.

Smoothing the way through ‚Äòlawnmower parenting‚Äô serves to make your children ready for smooth roads only. Constant hovering around your children only makes them even more reliant on your presence. As the person who loves them most, don‚Äôt ask yourself what you can do to help your children every day, but what you can do to help them help themselves. That‚Äôs a parenting action that will truly prepare them for the bumps, twists and turns of the life journeys stretching ahead of them.
~ How to raise a resilient child by Judith Locke

But in a world where so many aspects of our lives are mediated by our smartphones the techos also provide a more concrete record of our lives, says Yuri Kimura, who like most of Hobonichi‚Äôs staff is an avid user. ‚ÄúAs long as our life is offline, we need this,‚Äù she says. That‚Äôs a trend that‚Äôs shared with people all over the world as seen in the rise of the hugely popular pen-and-paper organisation system of bullet journals.
~ Why Japan is obsessed with paper by Edd Gent

That’s true. A digital record of our lives… is… digital. It’s not something I can reach out and hold physically. Writing something down on a planner, diary or journal, is a more concrete record of our lives.

items.content_html:
I was running a test and kept running into the error below. I would not allow myself to check-in my code unless my tests passed. Battled with this fates-cursed error for over an hour. I double-checked my test project app.config file and the relevant client.config files - everything looked right.

It turns out, there was a typo in the Web.config file for another service. See, the service method that I’m trying to test, was running inside another service. So, in addition to the test project’s app.config file, I also needed to double-check the other service’s Web.config file. And that other Web.config file had a fates-cursed typo on it…

The binding at system.serviceModel/bindings/basicHttpBinding does not have a configured binding named ‘BasicHttpBinding_IXXXXXX’. This is an invalid value for bindingConfiguration.

So, I noticed that unordered lists don’t show up correctly when using the Marfa theme. The list markers are missing. Adding the script below to my custom css seems to have fixed it.


#post-list li article ul li {
    list-style-type: disc;
}

Some things to try out in the next few days:

  • Switch out the Disqus comments system on my dev blog for utterances. Since it is a dev blog, I figure most of the people who visit would most likely have Github accounts.
  • Try to install Hyvor Talk on this micro.blog hosted blog. The first day I joined, I saw a post from someone saying they successfully installed it on their blog. After playing around with the custom theme option, I think it is doable. Will give it a try.

items.content_html:
Found another use for this micro.blog/micro journal of mine. I can use it to quickly store ideas for posts to write on my dev blog. Later on, I can come back here, find the post I wrote, flesh it out and post it on my dev blog. A possible benefit to would-be readers is that, even in its most basic form, it might already have enough info to help other people.

Normally, I would write these things down on my bullet journal. But I have noticed that I never seem to turn those notes into blog posts. Part of the problem is that it takes awhile for me to write down a solution to a technical problem. So, when writing things down, I sort of skimp on the details. When I come back to my notes, days, weeks, months later, I don’t have enough info to turn it into a blog post. I’m hoping this practice would help me get more content up on my dev blog.

items.content_html: Was going to try and welcome new bloggers whenever I see them pop-up on the other blogging platform I am on - something that I see happen often here on micro.blog. I went from trying to figure out how to respond to someone’s untitled post, to trying to figure out what to title my own post, to feeling like I am trying to advertise myself by doing so, to just closing the window. Without a dedicated Reply button, it’s just not the same.

üèÄ Okay first, the good news. The good news is that the Dallas Mavericks have clinched a playoff spot. Thanks to the Spurs for defeating the Grizzlies tonight. The Mavs have not been in the playoffs since 2016.

Now the bad news. The bad news is that the Mavs are on a 2-game losing streak since the restart of the NBA season. They could have won both games, but gave up the lead and lost at the end. They cannot close games. And their defense is so inconsistent. At this rate, if they don‚Äôt improve on those aspects of their game, I dont see them getting past the first round of the playoffs.

items.content_html:
Restart of the NBA season üèÄ could not have gone any better. The first two games back from the break went down to the wire. Both games ended with teams within 2 points of each other.

Brandon Ingram’s last second 3 point shot was in… before it rolled out. To be fair to the Jazz, they fought back to win the game. And Lebron, well Lebron is still Lebron. The long break from the game and his age did nothing to slow him down. Picked up his own miss to put the Lakers ahead at the end of the game.

Now I’m looking forward to the Mavericks vs Rockets game later tonight. Let’s go Mavs!

Both games ended with teams within 2 points of each other. Brandon Ingram's last second 3 point shot was in... before it rolled out. To be fair to the Jazz, they fought back to win the game. And Lebron, well Lebron is still Lebron. The long break from the game and his age did nothing to slow him down. Picked up his own miss to put the Lakers ahead at the end of the game. Now I'm looking forward to the Mavericks vs Rockets game later tonight. Let's go Mavs!

One more day before the restart of the NBA season üèÄ. Lakers vs Clippers tomorrow – should be an interesting game. Then Rockets vs Mavericks on Friday – a good chance to see if the Mavericks have improved during the break.

With the recent news of the coronavirus outbreak in baseball ‚öæÔ∏è, I can’t help but think that maybe, just maybe, the NBA got it right. Keeping everyone inside the NBA bubble in Florida to me is a great idea. The risk of getting infected is very low as long as no one sick is allowed in. Everyone inside can stay safe and focus on their game.
